Title: Atypical sign language development
Abstract: © 2020 - John Benjamins B.V.A major theme in Bencie Woll's research has been what the study of sign language and atypical signers who have neurological differences can teach us about language and cognition more generally. In this chapter, we focus on the growing literature relating to atypical sign language development, with an emphasis on Bencie's pioneering work in this field. We show that by studying atypical users of language we gain insights into language and cognitive processes that would not be obtained by studying typical users, or by limiting research to spoken languages. We review developmental research of individuals and groups with Landau-Kleffner Syndrome, Williams Syndrome, Autism Spectrum Disorder and Specific Language Impairment. Finally, we consider issues relating to intervention.
